turns.text: Uh do you want to give start on it
turns.label: qy^t

turns.text: Well I think for me - I Im from Alabama
turns.label: sd

turns.text: South Alabama and so I grew up in the midst of civil rights movement
turns.label: sd

turns.text: Uh in pretty liberal family for for that area at the time
And so I was very much part of all the uh you know what was going on there
turns.label: sd

turns.text: Uh my parents are pretty active and uh it was very scary and but now weve seen you know uh black people have lot more civil rights in that area and I guess all over than they did you know twenty years ago
turns.label: sd

turns.text: Theres still lot to be you know to be accomplished but --
turns.label: sv

turns.text: -- for me when I think about social change thats what I first think of because I can remember you know separate public restrooms and separate water fountains and --
-- sitting in the back of the bus and everything
You can relate to that Now see we didnt we dont have any of that because well like we live in the country --
turns.label: bf

turns.text: -- in Clarion County and uh we really didnt have things like that going on --
-- that we you know uh ran into So we kind of uh - I guess when I think of social changes I think think more of uh uh visiting habits of families --

Yeah that theres less visiting done I think on whole than there used to be - Used to be that you took the family whether the kids wanted to go or not you went visiting And uh today you know people they do visit but its not quite the same as uh what it was say twenty years ago thirty years ago
turns.label: b

turns.text: Right And I grew up in out in the country too basically in rural area --
turns.label: aa

turns.text: And so we were always at family in different - --
turns.label: sd

turns.text: But even now you know they dont even do that
turns.label: sv

turns.text: Well theyre so spread out I think has lot to do with it
turns.label: sv

turns.text: People peoples personal schedules are so busy
turns.label: sv

turns.text: Mainly because I lot of it has to do I think with more women working --
turns.label: sv

turns.text: -- in our family you know twenty years ago not that many of the women worked
turns.label: sd

turns.text: And now uh almost all the women work
turns.label: sv

turns.text: And so that means you know lot of lot of the social visiting and all was I think probably instigated by women --
turns.label: sv

turns.text: -- dont really care to go out and visit as much
And now uh - I mean my mother does not work and and she you know shes - finds herself pretty alone lot --
-- because most of her friends are working women
But even just social visits people dont do that anymore Youre right
turns.label: sv

turns.text: No huh-uh they dont do as much
turns.label: nn

turns.text: And people dont feel comfortable just to drop in on people --
turns.label: sv

turns.text: You have to make arrangements or have --
turns.label: sv

turns.text: Right you know you dont want to
turns.label: aa

turns.text: You want to make sure its okay or -
I guess we dont not to make invade peoples privacy or whatever
turns.label: sv

turns.text: Well that could be part of it I dont know for sure what it is I know our children mostly are scattered out at distance so we really dont have that even We dont -
turns.label: aa

turns.text: Well out of out of fifteen grandchildren in my family only two of us dont live within fifty miles
turns.label: sd

turns.text: And th- and most live within ten --
turns.label: sd

turns.text: -- or or twenty So but thats you know that is rural its rural family and --
-- most people didnt go away Im just one of the two --
-- that dont live in the you know even in the same state
Well apparently there must be work available for those --
turns.label: qy^d

turns.text: uh-huh Because around here theres really nothing for the young people no good I mean theres jobs Theres minimum wage jobs but uh to make good living there really around here there just isnt too much
turns.label: b

turns.text: uh-huh And I guess you know that would greatly affect social ch- i social change
turns.label: b

turns.text: Probably the job market has alwa- and the the economy --
turns.label: sv

turns.text: -- has always affected uh social change
So well theres the main things I can think of I really tried to think of some other things and I couldnt really
turns.label: sd

turns.text: Well I think just also you know the womens movement too has affected lot of social change
turns.label: sv

turns.text: I mean basically I think - now again where Im from in in Alabama thats not necessarily true --
-- because people do still get married right out of high school
But now out here in Texas where I am now thats very unusual
turns.label: sd

turns.text: Theyd rather get their life started first before -
turns.label: sv

turns.text: Most people get marrie- I mean get go to college or at least get job and even you know people are seem to lot of people seem to be engaged for long time before they get married --
turns.label: sv

turns.text: -- because they do want to be financially set up

Yeah well even to get school finished I think lot of times its better if they do finish their schooling before they settle in Because marriage takes lot of effort and concentration and if youre busy with school its I think its really difficult for family
turns.label: aa

turns.text: Right But probably uh you know more women being in in the work force also greatly greatly affects social change
turns.label: aa

turns.text: Because it affects child care and -
turns.label: sv

turns.text: Yeah I know my my daughter that lives in Pittsburgh she has two little boys and they theyve been in day care since you know - ones four and ones one --
turns.label: b

turns.text: -- and theyve done well Now I wouldnt want to do it that way but uh shes quite happy and the children seem quite adjusted
turns.label: sd

turns.text: Well and theyre you know theyre theyre saying right now we dont know what we just now are seeing the effects of day care on --
turns.label: sd

turns.text: -- the generation thats just now coming into --
-- the work force and in their twenties
They are the first generation that basically grew up with day care
turns.label: sv

turns.text: And so you know it remained to be seen exactly what that what that does
turns.label: sv

turns.text: uh-huh Now Im going to baby-sit my granddaughter Shes just eight weeks old so this will be new for me
turns.label: aa

turns.text: So uh but the others Im too far away to help them out at all
turns.label: sd

turns.text: Uh well I have son and daughter that live in Pittsburgh One in Maryland and one in Connecticut son in Connecticut
turns.label: sd

turns.text: Well theyre not too far though
turns.label: sv

turns.text: No but like Connecticut takes eight hours to drive home and uh its too far to you know really go too often
turns.label: aa

turns.text: Pittsburghs not quite so bad Its just couple hours Maryland maybe five hour drive
turns.label: sv

turns.text: Well I live like fourteen hours from home
turns.label: sd

turns.text: In fact Im Im driving tomor- Im Im driving home tomorrow so -
turns.label: sd

turns.text: To go be there for the Fourth of July
turns.label: sd

turns.text: Do you uh stay overnight on the way or you -
turns.label: qy

turns.text: No I can drive it all Its just me
turns.label: nn

turns.text: Okay well youre young enough yet to -
turns.label: bk

turns.text: Although its its it is pretty - I dont know I dont enjoy it that much
Its pretty much like get there and -
turns.label: sd

turns.text: Its work to get there Yeah
turns.label: sv

turns.text: Even with other people I basically just dont like to drive that far
turns.label: sd
